content: The "Internet Tax Freedom Act Amendments Act of 2007" changes the moratorium on internet taxes from 2007 to 2014. It also includes provisions for grandfathering states that tax internet access. The Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to clarify the definition of 'Internet access' for subsections (a) and (b) effective as of November 1, 2003. The Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to define 'Internet access' for subsections (a) and (b) as of October 21, 1998, with exceptions until June 30, 2008. The Internet Tax Freedom Act, as amended, provides exceptions until June 30, 2008, for a tax on Internet access that is generally imposed on telecommunications service purchased by a provider of Internet access. The Internet Tax Freedom Act, as amended, provides exceptions until June 30, 2008, for a tax on Internet access that is generally imposed on telecommunications service purchased by a provider of Internet access. An administrative agency of a State or political subdivision issued a ruling before July 1, 2007, or if there is litigation initiated before that date seeking to enforce such tax on Internet access in a manner inconsistent with the Act, no inference of legislative construction should be made. The Internet Tax Freedom Act, as amended, provides exceptions until June 30, 2008, for a tax on Internet access that is generally imposed on telecommunications service purchased by a provider of Internet access. No inference of legislative construction should be drawn from this subsection or the amendments made by the Internet Tax Freedom Act Amendments Act of 2007 for any period prior to June 30, 2008, with respect to any tax subject to specific exceptions. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. Section 1105 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to clarify the definition of "Internet access" as a service that enables users to connect to the Internet and includes the purchase, use, or sale of telecommunications by providers for this purpose. The definition of "Internet access" under the Internet Tax Freedom Act includes services that enable users to connect to the Internet and encompasses the purchase, use, or sale of telecommunications by providers for this purpose. The definition of "Internet access" under the Internet Tax Freedom Act includes services that enable users to connect to the Internet, access content, information, or other services offered online. This encompasses services like home pages, electronic mail, instant messaging, video clips, and personal electronic storage capacity. It does not include voice, audio, or video programming, or other products and services. The definition of "Internet access" under the Internet Tax Freedom Act includes services like home pages, electronic mail, instant messaging, video clips, and personal electronic storage capacity. It excludes voice, audio, or video programming, and other products and services that utilize Internet protocol and have a charge. The Internet Tax Freedom Act defines "Internet access" to include services like home pages, electronic mail, instant messaging, video clips, and personal electronic storage capacity. It excludes voice, audio, or video programming, and other products and services that utilize Internet protocol and have a charge. The Internet Tax Freedom Act defines "Internet access" to include services like home pages, electronic mail, instant messaging, video clips, and personal electronic storage capacity, provided independently or not packaged with Internet access. Telecommunications is defined as per the Communications Act of 1934 and includes communications services. The term 'telecommunications' is defined as per the Communications Act of 1934 and includes communications services. The term 'tax on Internet access' does not include a State tax effective November 1, 2007. The term 'tax on Internet access' excludes certain State taxes on commercial activity, modified gross receipts, taxable margin, or gross income of businesses, as per State law using specific terms. The term 'tax on Internet access' excludes certain State taxes on commercial activity, modified gross receipts, taxable margin, or gross income of businesses if enacted between specific dates and meeting certain criteria. The term 'tax on Internet access' excludes certain State taxes on commercial activity, modified gross receipts, taxable margin, or gross income of businesses if enacted between specific dates and meeting certain criteria. Additionally, the tax should be imposed on a broad range of business activity and not discriminatory towards providers of communication services, Internet access, or telecommunications. After November 1, 2007, states can modify taxes covered by clause (i) as long as the changes do not significantly limit the range of taxed business activities or disqualify the tax. No conclusions about the application of subparagraph (A) or (B) should be made based on this paragraph for periods before November. After November 1, 2007, states can modify taxes covered by clause (i) as long as the changes do not significantly limit the range of taxed business activities or disqualify the tax. No inference of legislative construction shall be drawn from this regarding the application of subparagraph (A) or (B) to any tax described in clause (i) for periods prior to November 1, 2007. SEC. 5. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to replace "telecommunications services" with "telecommunications" and to include enabling users to access internet content. Additionally, section 1108 regarding voice services is removed. SEC. 6. SUNSET OF GRANDFATHER PROVISIONS. This section states that certain states will no longer be exempt from taxes on Internet access if they have repealed such taxes more than 24 months before the enactment of this provision. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act and its amendments will be effective from November 1, 2007, applying to existing and future taxes, except as specified in the Internet Tax Freedom Act.
